snippet: On Oct. 18, 1968, the United States Olympic Committee suspended the medal-winning sprinters Tommie Smith and John Carlos and barred them from the Olympic Village for their conduct during the playing of "The Star-Spangled Banner" in Mexico City.
lead_paragraph: On Oct. 18, 1968, the United States Olympic Committee suspended the medal-winning sprinters Tommie Smith and John Carlos from the American national team and barred them from the Olympic Village for their conduct during the playing of "The Star-Spangled Banner" at a medal ceremony at the Summer Olympics in Mexico City. Mr. Smith, who won the gold medal, and Mr. Carlos, who took bronze in the 200-meter event, wore black gloves on the podium. As the American national anthem played, the two raised their fists in a gesture of support for the black power movement.

headline.main: Oct. 18, 1968 | American Olympic Medal Winners Suspended for Black Power Salutes
